title: AD review trivial items
body:
Copy-pasting from Alexey's mail at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/QRSNN9ZhsB5PXcMyPFn226DSgpM everything that is not coming up in the discussion thread.

If any of this spawns discussion, please remove it here and take it to a dedicated issue; I assume that all those can just be edited.

> Everywhere: header ==> header field (at least one instance in Section 5,
> there might be more)

> In Section 3.7: the first mention of URN needs a reference.

> In 4.1.1: RDAO type of 38 - IANA typically should be allowed to pick the
> next available value unless there was an early allocation. You should be
> prepared for this value to change.

> In 4.3:
> >  The well-known entry points SHOULD be provided to enable unicast
> discovery.
> 
> I don't see a new .well-known value being registered in the IANA
> Considerations section. Have I misintepreted what this mean?

This is referring to the existing .well-known/core discovery URI that is
heavily used in RD.

(The grouping of this requirement in the context of the section can be
improved still).

> In Section 5:
> 
> 
>       ep :=  Endpoint name (mostly mandatory).  The endpoint name is an
>          identifier that MUST be unique within a sector.  As the
>          endpoint name is a Unicode string, it is encoded in UTF-8 (and
>          possibly pct-encoding)
> 
> pct-encoding ==> pct-encoded

> At the end of section 5:
> 
> 
>    Req: POST /rd?ep=node1&base=http://[2001:db8:1::1] HTTP/1.1
>    Host: example.com
>    Content-Type: application/link-format
>    Payload:
>    </sensors/temp>;ct=41;rt="temperature-c";if="sensor",
>    <http://www.example.com/sensors/temp>;
>      anchor="/sensors/temp";rel="describedby"
> 
> This is not valid HTTP, I would rather you used a proper HTTP example. If
> you do, the line "Payload:" should be replaced with an empty line to
> separate payload from the header section.

I'll the rest of the items to this issue as I'm finishing my reply mail -- I'm just more comfortable leaving a mail draft open than a GitHub issue.

title: Say something about how limited devices can be

labels.name: expect reporter OK
labels.description: Assignee thinks it can be closed but is unsure; the reporter should close the bug if they agree.

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
From [Jaime's review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/vt7JiBeAI6XrkpKI1UWMbnMc9B8), again:

> p3 - "with limited RAM and ROM" Adding a reference to the expected RAM
> and ROM would be good. https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6970748/
> provides an estimation of <2kB of minimum RAM and <30kB of minimum ROM
> for common IoT OSs.

That's not trivial to answer, given an RD endpoint should reuse much of existing CoAP infrastructure on a device.

I'm looking through the RIOT example, but that's not particularly optimized and carries a command-line tool to manage the registration in a build that uses ~80k ROM and ~25k RAM, but that's largely package buffers (which are reasonably sized for additional applications but not required for the RD; RD itself consumes about 150 bytes RAM plus unknown on stack) and probably 1k of ROM from the RD application – I can try to refine those numbers, but anything more optimized would be better to look at.

Does anyone have numbers on how constrained an RD client can be?

title: In simple registration, the query of /.well-known/core should be allowed inline
body: When doing simple registration, I do not believe that it should be a requirement that the result MUST be returned prior to doing the query.  This allows for situations where the EP believes itself to be registered when in fact is is not because the query to /.well-known/core failed for some reason.  Additionally, the EP no longer has a cue as to when it can shut down because it does not know how long it will be before the RD performs the query operation.  If this is done inline then both of these situations are addressed.

title: Follow web link terminology
body:
Working with RFC8288 in CoRAL I noticed that we're a bit sloppy on some concepts of web linking. This manifests in two related issues:

* We're talking of link attributes, where that's a term nowhere defined. (Used by RFC6690, but possibly they mean "attributes of CoRE links" and not "Core's use of link attributes", and even there only in the chapter name.)
* The information model we describe is more the model of the serialized data; the data model makes no distinction, for example, between `<c>;rel="b";anchor="a",<c>;rel="b2";anchor="a"` and `<c>;rel="b b2";anchor="a"`.

The latter is something we can IMO let slide on account of practical readers having both in mind. The former poses the danger of aggravating the careless use of "link attributes" that'd describe the link-as-a-whole (something not covered by the data model, and thus incompatible with different serializations), but can easily be fixed in a search-and-replace PR coming right up.

title: Drop examples of protocol-negotiation
body:
Those were explicitly labelled as "not to show up in published
versions", and as we're approaching that, it's time for them to go.

title: "No more jumping" edits
body:
This is the edit series suggested in https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/164#issuecomment-439012643, and covers all the bycatch of the change in a (for my changes) large series.

Effectively, it rolls back the "administrative interface" change to address #164, which IMO was of good intentions but in practice caused more confusion -- plus the size of what might be the appendix interface was reduced to managable size by the removal of groups-as-an-entity and the commit addressing #77.

The changes in logical order (commit order tries to produce readable diffs that reduce the chances of errors sneaking in):
* Drop the GET on the registration resources (see #77)
* Drop fig-hierarchy (that figure made sense when there were four entities to it, but by the end it was a relic without use)
* Move group stuff into an own area (see #164), including examples that got lost in unrelated sections
* Move the administrative parts roughly back to their original locations to address #164: "Operations on the Registration Resource" to after registration (as it is how a registration continues its life cycle); endpoint lookup to the end of the lookup part (emphasising more on the resource lookup).

This reverts previous changes in two places: The registration management (administrative interface) from e7836496e95e7cf208e471928ef5a5d324f8f6d1 (as argued above), and the move of RD-Groups out of an appendix from f3ae77c43023f97fc0846f856aed5f913edea9a7 (which I missed when reviewing Peter's additions to the new-groups branch and should have protested right away; see second part of discussion in #164).

title: Coral precautions alternatives
body:
lookup: Change example of alternative formats from HTML to links-json...
    
...  and set the expectation that more elaborate formats will not use this lookup interface.
    
This is an alternative way of catering for futuer formats after Peter's comment on #177; it means fewer changes, but reduces the usability of the defined lookup interfaces to link-format-ish media types for lack of the changes suggested there.
    
---

I prefer to go the other route, but specification-wise both are consistent with their examples and extensible. (To extend this, define a new interface and possibly update this document that it's sufficient to implement any lookup interface; to extend the original version in #177, just define a link format. If we did neither, any update would need to reach into the document and allow the updates of #177, incurring the danger of almost-but-not-quite compatibility).

Both versions include commit 9e1a7499253e63e4450798f0b2ac70d95a3a987e to say that media types in registration have laxer equivalence requirements; the original requirement was not even fulfilled for application/link-format itself (not every link in its data model can be expressed in its serialization), let alone any other format.

title: consistency of intro, abstract and other sections
Explicitly state that base= is always reported in EP lookup
body: Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/169

title: Provisions for supporting CoRAL with the RD
body:
* Allow relative references in lookup results if the format caters for it

* Allow fluctuation in the number of resulting links

  This is because CoRAL would represent `</x>;rel="a b";anchor="/y"` as two links.

  One might argue that the number of links should be per representation, but that'd preclude any proxy based media type conversion.

* Allow non-lookup links.

  This is not only for CoRAL but (as in the example) for HTML. It also allows other forms of self description, eg. `<?page=1&count=5>;rel="next"` which I had wanted to allow since Michael mentioned self links.

  Note that (as the HTML example shows) this would already have occurred within the behavior we have indicated, but not allowed.

title: Use "Accept" option rather than "Content-Format" in negotiation
body:
A "Content-Format" on a request means a different thing (format
indication rather than negotiation).

I don't consider this a factual change in the protocol, as the old use
conflcits with the option's definition, and after all, those tables are
only illustrative.

title: Demote links-json from normative reference
body:
As links-json went back from the IESG to the WG, chances are it won't be
available as a normative reference, especially given that there's a
tendency to do it right together with CoRAL rather than stay 6690
roundtrippable.

The content formats were removed from the interaction templates (and
replaced with more general phrasing on "web link" media types). The
request to RFC editor to replace TBD64 etc ct= values was turned into a
note to the reader. Examples stayed in, but received notes explicit
references to the draft (to indicate that this example is using a WIP
format).

---

This was not explicitly talked about so far in the interim or WG meeting, but given the state of links-json as it was presented seems to be the logical conclusion.

title: Replace Modernized with Limited link format
body:
Rather than redefining RFC6690, we now just allow the common subset.

As this touched some 5988 references, I fixed the ref-to-obsolete-rfc issues right in here in a follow-up commit.

title: Ensure introduction and abstract are in line with principles
body: See https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/CW0eKCtISPFJUmHQmkuUXD31iUo

title: Drop Modernized Link Format in favor of references to more modern formats
body:
The outcome of the 2018-10-24 interim w/rt [Klaus' review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/N4gZcyFuIsXQ9GwUBAEsy8fwfZc) of the use of Modernized Link Format is what I'd outline like this:

* The WG has no interest in keeping 6690 alive by having a bis
* links-json/-cbor was pushed back to the WG, and it looks like it won't follow the troublesome parts of 6690 any more

Therefore, my proposed course of action is to

* Remove Modernized Link Format, leaving it in only as a set of limitations the submitted links MUST follow. (Effectively creating a subset of Link Format that can be expected to be interoperable even as people implemented Modernized Link Format or similar, but not specifying any new behavior).
    * currently we say that submitted documents SHOULD be in that subset, but mandate that Modernized Link Format be applied by the server in order to allow the rare 6690-impossible things.
* State that for some use cases, Link Format is therefore not suitable, and other formats (like links-json or CoRAL, both informative references) need to be used to be able to express some links.
* (Maybe in the interop spec) point out where variation is to be expected given widespread bugs in RFC6690 implementations.

As Peter pointed out, that should be a matter of days to do plus something in the order of magnitude of a week for reviews -- I'll be starting to write the text Soon, so we'll have a proposed text for Bangkok.

Any comments before I start?

title: Appendix late fixes
body: The promised changes to the appendices from discussion with Peter

title: Reporting of explicit base address
body:
Implementations in Friday's plug test had different behaviors when it came to reporting the base address in endpoint lookup: Mine reports it unconditionally, while Jim's reports it only if explicit.

I think that it should always be reported, but we might want to phrase A.5 stronger to enforce that.

title: Registration take-over

labels.name: interop-spec
labels.description: This issue needs no (more) changes to the document, but the next iteration of the interop spec.

body:
Friday's plug test has spurred discussion as to whether a registration can be "taken over" by a CT. There, a client registers simply in 3, and then something else (a CT?) finds its registration and deletes it in step 12.

This describes a procedure that we do not describe, that is, a CT jumping in at a simple registration and treating it as a third party registration from there on -- whereas we say that "[a]dditional operations on the registration resource cannot be executed because no registration location is returned".

I suggest we change the test procedure not to include behavior we don't specify, and to test the explicit deregistration with the full or third party registration instead. Then, the text we already have on that there can't be additional operations on the registration resource should suffice to indicate that such behavior is not expected.

(One thought that had led to the discussion was that registration resources might not be available on all URI schemes, for whereas an RD serving on coap, coap+tcp and http might have three equivalent directory resources at ${scheme}://${ip}/rd for all values of scheme, a registration resource might still only be available to the client at a particular scheme.)

title: plug test description: dealing with multiple hosts

labels.name: interop-spec
labels.description: This issue needs no (more) changes to the document, but the next iteration of the interop spec.

body:
It's a minor thing but was observed in the plug test: When the client part is played by a software participant (as opposed to an embedded participant with different network stacks for node1..3), chances are that all nodes run on the same IP address and consequently need different ports.

Not sure what best course of action is; I'd probably go with suggesting dedicated ports for node1..3 to listen on, if it's not 5683 for all of them. (Plus a note on which ports are recommended for network monitoring in the tests.)

Given I'd like to run the next plug test with F-Interop support, I'll gather feedback from there as well as to whether they have good experience with any particular mode here.

title: common set of resources for a group
Avoiding link-local addresses
body:
Today's plug test gave us a <coap://[fe80::2c7c:b7ff:feac:bda8%tapbr0]/sensors/temp> address as a result of (manual simulation of) a "Finding" step yielded a link-local address, and simple registration was performed to that.

We might want to add in the finding steps that link-local addresses should be avoided, and maybe  that RDs that can be found via such addresses might want to refuse such registrations unless they have some very explicit knowledge that'd allow them to translate the addresses -- though the latter is probably overly specific.

I'm not familiar enough with the interaction of multicast addresses with link-local addresses, that'll need some research. In my practical experiments, registrants have not used any `::1` or `fe80:` to talk to multicast addresses even though it would have worked, but I only tried ff05 addresses so far and will try more.

(The most worrysome case to me seems to be a simple client doing a `POST coap://[ff02::fd]/.wk/c?ep=mynode`, but I don't think we allow that anyway. The next most worrysome is the same client doing a `GET coap://[ff02::fd]/.wk/c?rt=core.rd`, receiving a response from a fe80 address, and then doing simple registration there. Will experiment...)

title: Criterion for being in administrative interface
body:
Moving this from mail (why can't github link to arbitrary URLs? Original mail: <mid:20180927143411.GD26269@hephaistos.amsuess.com>) here, as the current structure seems to have caused confusion with several readers:

> > Appendix may also be section 7.
> > The criterion was the manipulation of registration resources.
> > That got a bit mixed in the group context.
> 
> I don't think that's a useful criterion from a spec user's point of view. To me it'd make more sense to split them based on its expected use, be it "EP-side and everything else" (moving all lookup to appendix) or "EP's operations and resource lookup are regular operation,
> everything else is administrative".
> 
> I have no strong feelings either way whether it's a section 7 or an appendix.

Concrete proposal (I agree that this is yet another overhaul, and am happy to have it downvoted, but at least *if* we change the structure one more time we should get it right)

* Have a section describing discovery. That would encompass -15 sections 4, 4.1, 5.2
* Have a section "The Registration Interface", from current 5.3*, A.1 and A.2 ("Everything a Registrant-EP needs to know"). I advocate deferring A.3 to "Could be specified (like iPATCH (A.4))", and those two would be footnotes of that section.
* Leave 7 (lookup interface) largely as it is
* Move Groups into the appendices (they're very disconnected from the rest, and might even have potential for splitting off, given their practical application is under discussion)
* Turn the rest of Appendix A into "Administrative lookup interfaces", describing endpoint and group lookup.

That'd mean that implementors of clients (EP as well as lookup) have a single chapter of interactions they can follow, and only implementors of CTs need to look into the appendices.

title: Talk of "relative references" and "URIs" rather than of "absolute URIs"
body:
The previous text did not match my intentions, back when I thought of
"absolute URIs" as "URI references that are already in URI form", where
actually they are a construct intended for protocols to express that the
fragment part does not take part in the dereferencing process.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/153

---

Will merge soon unless it conflicts with someone's private branches or draws other negative comments.

title: Term "absolute URI" used wrong

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
> > * p2: An absolute URI can well have fragments; what matters is that the
> > scheme is there.
> That's not what I found on Internet e.g. wikipedia. I was amazed, but never contradict the authorities.

Oh, I see. But then I've been using the term wrong. In ABNF terminology
for RFC3986, there's a "URI" (thing-with-scheme), a "relative-ref" and a
"URI-reference" (which can be relative or not). I had thought it wise to
talk of absolute URIs when I mean thing-with-scheme to disambiguate
"URI" from "URI-reference", unaware that "absolute-URI" is even stricter.

As we are not designing a communication protocol, we should not use the
term "absolute URI", but talk of "URI" or (if ambiguous) a "complete
URI". I'll need to patch that in the draft, sorry for the mess and
thanks for pointing it out.

title: moved lookup ep en gp to appendix A
Simplify luminary example

The luminary of the example previously discovered its group addresses by
looking up its own registration resource (which it did not know because
it was entered by a CT), and via that its groups.

As long as the device does not need to know its own registration
resource, the same can be achieved in a single step by looking up groups
that contain it directly, based on the address it would originally have
compared the endpoint results against.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/143

---

Like with #145: @petervanderstok, that's the example where you know all the rationales, feel free to merge or discard.

title: Fix misrepresentation of RFC6690's rules
body:
This responds to a comment from Jim on the use of the term "Origin" in
RFC6690 which I had previously missed.

Given that the old 6690-style documents are thus a lot less powerful, the
text goes from "Submitted documents should be the same in both
interpretations, and the RD can use either" to "Submitted documents
should be the same, and the RD interprets them 8288 style".

A paragraph was added that defines precisely what it means to interpret
it 8288 style.

Several outdated references to where resolution happens have been
removed.

---

The "8288 style interpretation" is called Modernized Link Format; I'd be happy of any better names, but am convinced we need to name it somehow to avoid vaguely describing the same thing again and again.

title: Allow paths in con

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
I'm aware this is a discussion we've already had, but back then we dropped it for its complexity *and because we had no use cases*.

Matthias has brought up use cases for allowing a path in the con [on the mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/NjJVmLltA8FzeHIXkTcxdjMR_2I) as part of the -13 reviews. He argues that a gateway bridging into a non-CoAP world would want to register its proxees (is that a word?) individually, and if it doesn't use name-based virtual hosting (which is kind of rare in CoAP and needs wildcard DNS records), could go for path-based hosting.

As I see it, this would be a trivial addition from the RD point of view ("just allow it"). The onus is on the endpoint / gateway to do it right, ie. to never use path-absolute URI references unless they mean it.

What *does* make this a bit more complicated is that none of the content formats we currently describe allows using that meaningfully -- but we are not limiting the RD to those content formats, and they may (and hopefully will) still change while we're finishing RD.

On the editing track, I would keep those cases out of the examples (I'm game for building a test suite, but the examples shouldn't be that). Then, the editing becomes a matter of replacing "specified URI MUST NOT have a path component" with "typically does not have a path component", adding the one or the other "typically", and being done with it.

(This would also make https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/123 obsolete, as those components would be allowed).

@petervanderstok (and possibly @jimsch), I'd assume you won't be too happy with (based on previous discussions of that topic), but do you see Matthias' point, or could point out concrete issues you see from allowing this?

title: Forbid Location-Query in registration resources, clean up Location vs…
body:
….  Location-Path

Location-Query has not been allowed so far but not forbidden either.
This makes a decision against allowing a query component on grounds of
potential conflict with query arguments added later at the
Registration Update operation.

The issue of URI templates that would need modification to do the right
thing (become {&lt,con,...} for registration update rather than
{?lt,con,...} if query is present) additionally weighs in favor of
disallowing them.

Various occurrences of "Location", "Location-Path" and "location"
throughtout the document have been updated to use the correct term for
the HTTP header, the CoAP option and the resulting URI, respectively.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/122

---

Submitting a "no Location-Query" proposal as announced on <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/_iNK2CFnpy2P4H-MMEm_mjMpytk>; I happily make the opposite proposal based on this too if someone has an idea of how to deal with the conflict in the update operation and feels strongly torwards the other direction.

title: Simple registration: allow or forbid optimistic success response

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
Two of the current implementations have different behavior when it comes to simple registrations:

* Jim's sends an ACK, but belays the Success response to when the .well-known/core has been obtained.
* Mine sends Success anyway to acknowledge the EP's intent to register, and only logs an error if something later goes wrong.

I think that Jim's is the better behavior; mine was motivated by consideration for clients that have a limited number of open exchanges (1), and might answer 5.03 for as long as they have outstanding CONs themselves.

IMO we should either prescribe Jim's behavior or add a warning that the Success indication does not necessarily mean too much. Which would you prefer?

title: can hosts relation value change context in update
body:
6.  Inferred context based on source IP when an update is done.  If no
con is provided, is that supposed to be checked again to see if it is
"right"?
Only if we did the infer to begin with?

My interpretation of the current text is:
When a  registration is done with the same ep and d values, the old
registration is removed and a new one with the new parameter values is
created at a new location.
That means that the value of con
is specified in the registration without any memory of earlier values.

This is not the sequence that I was looking for.

POST /rd?ep=node1
   - payload contains the set of resources the register.
   - returns a location of /rd/yyyy

POST /rd/yyyy?ep=node1
   - payload is empty.

In the first post, the rd will infer a context based on how the registration
is done.  The second post just says that the TTL value is to be refreshed
back to the life-time value.  However, the inferred context could also be
changed.

Thanks for the example; it would take me long to figure this out otherwise.

Reading the update specification, the ep=node1 is illegal in the update. Specifying ep means creating a new registration.

sending the update
POST /rd/yyy will update the lt value.
It is allowed to change the value of con in the update POST specification.
The question is:
When an updating ep, different from the registering one, sends the update of lt, does the context change to the hosts relation value of the updating ep.

My gut reaction is no. it does not change the context value in the RD because that needs an explicit ?con= in the update specification.

A warning in the RD text to this effect looks reasonable.

title: Explicit syntax for hierarchy-traversing lookup
body:
This makes server-side implementation easier and lets RD-aware caching proxies know where to look.

---

This is the controversial change mentioned in today's meeting that'd address the last of draft-amsuess-core-rd-replication's suggestions.

If the optional middle paragraph were left out, the rule can be expressed about as briefly as the previous version.

On the "pro" side,

* this avoids unneccessary (and possibly confusing) matching against unintended attributes of the wrong entity,
* reduces the interactions that need to be considered when picking a parameter name and
* transports the intention of the client more clearly,

but on the "contra" side

* is more verbose in the query URI and
* possibly harder to understand from the specification text.

As I said, I'd like to have this change because I think it makes some caching cases easier, but if the authors decide that it's not worth it, I'm OK with not having it as well.

title: Type representation
body:
The Resource Directory uses some query parameters or link attributes to represent the types of the endpoints and resources. For instance, rt (resource type) or ep (endpoint type). 
However, the representation of the types is not defined in the Resource Directory document and it seems that the different endpoints can represent the different type values as they wish. 

Not having an standardized representation of the different types can lead to undesirable outcomes. For instance,  let's assume that a humidity sensor registers itself as a "humidity" resource type.  Now, there is another endpoint that has been manufacture in a Spanish speaking country and performs a resource lookup of all the humidity resource types but it looks for "humedad" instead. "Humedad" is the Spanish word for "humidity":  
  ` Req: GET /rd-lookup/res?rt=humedad`

In this particular case, the Resource Directory will not be able to match the search with the humidity sensor and the search will not appear in the lookup results.

I know that is very difficult to match all the possible endpoint types but it would be good to define what is allow and what is not as a value of a type. Shall do always be expressed in English? Shall do always be a name or verb?

title: Demonstrate interoperability in interop
body:
(This is more of a task than an issue, but should be tracked anyway)

Given that RD is stabilizing, we should have a remote plugtest of the existing implementations.

title: Interactions of the "con" attribute
body:
A number of questions about the "con" attribute.

1.  Can it appear in a link during registration or is it just synthesized by the RD on lookup of resources?
If yes,
2.  Is the value of "con" on the resource link modified by changing the "con" value on the endpoint?  Does it make a difference if the value on the resource matches the old value on the endpoint

title: Lookup of resources in groups
body:
Preparing for the IETF100 presentation I reviewed the role of groups in the RD, and given they are introduced with a focus on being discoverable multicast groups, I think I may have left that out of consideration when generalizing the lookup operations.

There might be a class of desirable lookup operations that queries for resources on a multicast address: "Which resources are there in a multicast group?", the answer to which question would be typed links targetting a multicast address; in terms of -12's lookup examples:

    Req: GET /rd-lookup/XXX&rt="light"
    </west>;rt="light";anchor="coap://[ff35:30:2001:db8::1]",
    </east>;rt="light";anchor="coap://[ff35:30:2001:db8::1]"

I'm unsure as to how that query should be formed exactly, and which links should be listed (those available on some devices? those on all?), but I think that those links should be in some form discoverable.

* Are such links something we want to make discoverable in an RD?
* Do we have enough information to decide which resources are accessible in a group?
* What metadata do we have on those links? (Eg. is it rt="light" if all nodes that have such a relative reference say it is?)
* If we can't or don't want supply those links (yet), is it justified to introduce groups as a "logical grouping of endpoints for the purpose of group communications", when all there is to it w/rt group communication is the ability to tell its multicast address in a group attribute?

Strawman proposal assuming all links are valid candidates:

Add an optional-to-implement lookup interface Group Resource (core.rd-lookup-gpres). It returns only links whose anchor was originally a relative reference, and re-interprets them once for each addressed group the link's endpoint is member of. Links that have become duplicate (as keyed by target, anchor and rel) are aggregated into one link, and their attribute lists are reduced to only those attributes common to all links in the aggregate. (rt=, if= and ct= attributes are not filtered out when they mismatch between the aggregated links, but are limited to their intersection value set.) The links are filtered after aggregation, and can match as aggregates, match their group or match an attribute present on all the endpoints whose links were aggregated.

title: Groups and domains
body:
Brought up by Jim [on the mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/puP0Nv8sZnL-hW5vKQvCUvAaGRw):

> When registering groups, is there a requirement that all of the endpoints be in the same domain as the group is?

[Christian] That's the idea implied in the hierarchy, but probably answered better by Michael or Peter who use the domain concept more than I do.

[Peter] My cut feeling is "no". Groups may be part of other domains than the contributing endpoints. One might think of domain hierarchies. e.g. endpoint in room domains, multicast in enveloping corridor domain. I prefer to leave this to users of RD and not add extra rules.

title: Multicast heuristic: use "All CoAP Nodes"
body:
The -12 draft suggests as a heuristic to ask at `coap://[ff02::1]/.well-known/core?rt=core.rd*`.

There is a multicast address for All CoAP Nodes, I suggest we use that (would be `coap://[ff02::fd]/...`).

title: Registration expiry and group membership
body:
We are explicit about Registration Removal ending group membership, but do not say the same about the eventual deregistration from a timeout (only "The RD MAY eventually remove the registration resource for the purpose of resource recovery and garbage collection.  If the Registration Resource is removed, the endpoint will need to re-register.")

A simple "[garbage collection], and remove it from any group it belongs to." would IMO suffice.

title: RD federation: group members from foreign RDs
body:
Jim Schaad [brought this up](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/puP0Nv8sZnL-hW5vKQvCUvAaGRw):

> When creating a group registration, can the link to an endpoint be on a different resource directory?  This second RD could be either on a different machine or on the same machine (i.e. coap vs coaps).  If the answer is no, then do we need to think about some type of relation attribute in the case that multiple are listed somewhere?

title: Version parameter

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
I'm just removing an in-text TODO about adding a version parameter.

Taking this to the issue tracker so it won't get lost -- but IMO we have sufficient ways for extensibility in that both individual features and completely new versions can be announced via the rt. If a client wants to utilize a particular feature, the RD can announce that as `rt="core.rd-res vnd.my-feature"` at the URI discovery step, and if at some point in time a backwards-incompatible successor to RD appears, it will just say `rt="core.rd2"`.

(Assigning to @petervanderstok because you had added that TODO, feel free to close without further comment if this has become obsolete).

title: Parent-from-child lookup: examples vs. text
body:
Text and examples are currently consistent that any link parameters of the "container" (group for endpoint, endpoint for link) can transitively match a query, so `/lkp/res?et=foo` gives all resources hosted on an endpoint with et=foo.

As Michael pointed out in #35, there are inconsistencies in the reverse direction: An example shows that `/lkp/gp?ep=node1` gives groups that contain that endpoint, which is not covered by the text on lookup

It sounds sane to have an "any matches" between endpoint and group, and the same logic would allow finding the endpoint that registered a particular link ("Who said `<t123.pdf>;rel=alternate;ct=65001;anchor="http://www.example.com/sensors/t123"`?") which is useful because we don't have reification inside link-format (which I think is good because it's still for constrained devices). So we could just say that the search criterion extends in both directions, and it is sufficient to match at either a container or something contained in it.

On the other hand, from the implementation PoV, this means that all gp and ep lookups with query parameters need to traverse all registered resources. I wouldn't mind, but other implementors might.

(Even if we reach quick agreement on this, I doubt a text update for this will make it into -12 :-/ )

title: Make the registration idempotent at request level
body:
The description of the Registration interface describes it as
idempotent, I think it should be idempotent on CoAP and not only on
application level -- the same request results in the same response with
no further state change.

As to what happens when the re-registration arrives with a *different*
set of links, there we have options; I went for "replaces the
registration" here, but a 4.09 *in that case* would be just as valid an
option.

@petervanderstok, that topic came up with the removal of the plurality removal at https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/pull/78#discussion_r147684686. Do you agree with the basic proposition of "an unmodified request should be 2.04", and do you think replacing is the right way, or 4.09 if the links don't match?

title: Lookup: empty as 4.04 is incompatible with observation
body:
Jaime's example in https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/74#issuecomment-339682381 (which is a good example independent of whether it'll go into the text or not) is incompatible with the current lookup definition that empty lookups return 4.04 -- if a query is empty initially, the first addition to it can't be observed because 4.xx states can't be.

I propose that lookups can just return empty ("an empty set is different from no set at all", and is successful), and 4.04 be removed from the list of described failure modes.

As I understand, we only mean a single mechanism here (but describe once the idea and once the implementation), and I think we should unify those two sections.

title: Observing lookups operation in the Resource Directory

labels.name: expect reporter OK
labels.description: Assignee thinks it can be closed but is unsure; the reporter should close the bug if they agree.

body:
Hi,

Right now, the RD document does not specified an operation to retrieve a lookup query and keep the query updated by the RD over a period of time.

That type of operation would be very useful when CoAP endpoints want to continuously query for the existence of specific resources in the Resource Directory.  

Even though the 'observe' operation can be applied to the GET operation, the RD specification does not specify the possibility of observing a query and the existing RD applications are ignoring that possibility right now. On the other hand, the observe RFC is not strictly defining the 'observation' of queries, it is just specifying the 'observation' of resources.

title: Plurality should be per-registration
body:
Granted, I don't really understand what purpose the plurality definition serves, but a clarification in https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/pull/69 ("... within the directory resource") brings this up:

If (as it is currently defined) plurality is checked between any two links in the whole RD, any two registrations that contain a static statement between external URIs (like the one in A.2) creates link plurality.

Such links are perfectly legal in a .well-known/core document, so why should they not be permissible in an RD?

Assigning @petervanderstok because your change triggered this, but feel free to reassign to whoever understands plurality best (I don't remember who introduced the concept).

* et should become just one of the registrable endpoint attributes (registry is already being prepared as RD parameter registry, but needs some work)
* lookup should allow using any of those registered attributes
* lookup should define how endpoint attributes are used in resource lookups (after all, `/rd-lookup/res?et=power-node` should be possible even though none of the resource links actually carry that attribute)

This PR is not final as it is, but will track my branch as I'm assembling (and possibly rewriting/rebasing) commits for this change.

title: "registration resource" used ambiguously
body:
The term "registration resource" is used ambiguously in the current document:

Sometimes, it refers to the particular resource created for a single endpoint's registration (eg. `/reg/1234`). At other occasions, it refers to the resource at which endpoints can registrer (eg. `/rd`).

I'm currently out of ideas on which terms to best use, would appreciate input and post an update if I come up with anything that's not "registration endpoint" (endpoint term being otherwise using in the CoAP netloc sense)  and "endpoint location" (endpoint again, and Location because of the header that sent the client there).

title: ER: modelling link-format serialization vs. modelling semantics

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body: Working with the ER model of `.well-known/core` in preparation of explanations around the use of anchor and href, I noticed that the model is something between a model of the link-format serializations and the web links data model. It uses much of the serialization's terminology ("anchor" and "href"), and refers to some cardinalities as they appear in the serialization (eg. anchor is 0-1 because it may be omitted), but at other places alludes to the data model (eg. rel has cardinality 0+, which reflects that a link can have several relations, but in the serialization they all get space-joint into 0-1 rel parameters). The model is now much closer to the serialization than the semantic model, and I think we should stay with that to keep the document from becoming too abstract. (Plus, I don't know which applications start breaking when we make `;rel=x;foo=bar,;rel=y;foo=baz` into `;rel="x y";foo=bar;foo=baz` which we could when we say the RD's data model is the abstract web linking model). Are we OK with the model reflecting the serialization and not the semantics? If if should reflect the serialization, the only discrepancies I spotted are that cardinality of rel and con are 0-1 (that count being low is probably another hint that it should stay this way).

title: Link model clarifications (mainly con=)
body:
This is the documenting text to the changes worked out first on the examples in #45.

It does not (yet) contain explaining overall text, but updates the various smaller mentions of the `con` parameter to fit together. It does change the semantics of using `con` on a registration update, but I believe that the previous wording was not what the original authors had intended. (Previously, an endpoint registering over TCP would need to explicitly repeat its con on every update).

title: Fixes for the idnits checker
body:
I've had to override the commit-time check for [idnits](https://tools.ietf.org/tools/idnits/) recently; these edits make the document idnits clean again.

I don't expect much controversy over those, but @petervanderstok, are you OK with labelling scheme://host:port as "con" in the diagram? (As it was, it's too wide for an RFC).

title: iana-registry: used in lookup?
body:
The "RD Parameters" subregistry is set up in the IANA considerations, but only referenced at the registration interface.

The lookup interface allows lookup by parameters of the same names (and page and count are exclusively used for lookup), but doesn't make a reference to the iana-registry.

Next steps (→CA): Add a reference to lookup interface description (and reviewing that text, decide on whether that does create linkage to any other existing registry).

title: Registration with plain cryptographic identity
body:
Currently, we prescribe that the registering endpoint needs to identify itself with at least an endpoint name, while we allow the RD to be configured to assign a domain based on its configuration.

We could allow the endpoint identifier to be absent as well, at least in principle (eg. make it a "SHOULD be set" but no syntactical requirement on its presence), and the RD's configuration then would need to set an endpoint name (like it can now do with a domain), or the RD would refuse the registration like it can now do for unauthenticated hosts. (The RD interface right now doesn't allow a 4.01 Unauthorized response, even though the security considerations indicate that that can happen.)

This would allow endpoints that have just enough persistent state to have their cryptographic identity in form of a PSK to register at the RD. Note that for those cases (and PSK seems not to be too uncommon in the CoRE security scenarios), the RD already needs to have received (or have a way to fetch) configuration about that key, which easily can contain a default (or the only permissible) endpoint name for that key.

I'd write a pull request to that respect unless controversial discussion about this starts here.

(This was fleshed out from in a discussion with Pekka Nikander during ACM ICN about very constrained devices).

title: clarified hosts and con relation for ER and 5.3.2
Group registration: identifcation of registered endpoints
body:
With the new EP and GP lookup link-format bodies (solving #21), the payload of a group creation has become odd: They are now the only place where a `<>;ep=...` can occur.

From how we express the model in link-format in other places, IMO the cleanest way of creating a group with members would be to address the members by their respective registration resources -- ie. if

~~~
POST /rd?ep=node1 → Created /reg/11
POST /rd?ep=node2 → Created /reg/12
~~~

then the group that contains both would be constructed with

~~~
POST /rd-group?gp=grp-of-some
</reg/11>,</reg/12>
~~~

which is consistent with group lookups, but requires a group manager that only knows the group members by their endpoint names to look them up first through the EP lookup interface.

The alternatives are to keep things as they are (and spell out that the hrefs are ignored and the ep= attributes are used like EP query attributes), or to come up with something that is not direct link-format at all (possibly `</rd-lookup?ep=node1>,</rd-lookup?et=some-type>` to create a group with all nodes of some-type and the node named node1).

My personal preferences are (in decreasing order) `</reg/11>,</reg/12>`, something-different and keep-as-is, but it's not a very strong preference.

title: anchor ambiguities

labels.name: expect reporter OK
labels.description: Assignee thinks it can be closed but is unsure; the reporter should close the bug if they agree.

body:
With the normal directory queries, if the external  representation is 

    </sensors/temp>;if="sensor",
    </sensors/light>;if="sensor"

Then a query of ?href="/sensors" would return all of the items.  On the
other hand if the external representation is

    </temp>;if="sensor";anchor="/sensors",
    </light>;if="sensor";anchor="/sensors"

The same query would return nothing.

This behavior is leading me to some questions on how the context field
should be processed or ignored when doing filtering as part of the RD code.

Suppose you publish

Context="coap://example.org/sensors"

    </temp>;if="sensor",
    </light>;if="sensor"


** Should a get with ?href="/sensors" against the path returned from the
post return any of the entries or should it find zero entries?  (Section
5.4.3 Read Endpoint links)

** Does the answer change if I do the query against the full resource
directory rather than a single subset of the RD? (Section 7)

Given that a response to a section 7 query would return

    <coap://example.org/sensors/temp>;if="sensor",
    <coap://example.org/sensors /light>;if="sensor"

** Should a query with ?href="/temp" return a response with one element - or
is the full context string needed for this type of query?  (i.e.
?href="coap://example.org/sensors*")

** I have already asked one question about anchors in the prior message, but
normalization for a response seems to be a problem here.

Jim

[edited by chrysn to make links readable after formatting]

title: more con context

labels.name: expect reporter OK
labels.description: Assignee thinks it can be closed but is unsure; the reporter should close the bug if they agree.

body:
Hi Jim,

Indeed, the text 5.3.4 can confuse people.
We have added an entity-relationship model to he draft that shows that context is an attribute of the registration.
Currently, all links of the registration resource share the same context.
Citing the context when comparing links in the same registration resource is superfluous.
I think that 5.3.1 should read about all links over all registration resources within an RD.

Text will be modified.

Thanks for pointing this out.

Peter

Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-08-31 06:55:
In reading through and working on implementing this draft, I have found what
appears to me to be conflicting language on the context parameter.

Section 5.3.4 indicates that context + target could have collisions and that
this is likely to occur if there are multiple configuration tools.  This
text appears to me to indicate that the context can be different for each
link in a registration resource.  Each update could provide a different
context.  (I will note that the text probably needs to discuss dealing with
both normalization of the context and building the full URI from the context
and target when doing the comparison.  The pairs
<coap://ep.example.com:5683, /foo/bar> and  <coap://ep.example.com/foo,
/bar> should probably compare as identical.

Section 5.4.1 in the third paragraph talks about updating the lifetime and
context in the same paragraph  Since I know that the lifetime is a parameter
of the registration resource, it is reasonable from the context to assume
that the context would also be a parameter of the registration resource
rather than of a link.

In my opinion, these are conflicting concepts of what the meaning of context
is.  Would it be possible to figure out which is supposed to be correct and
both let me know and update the document?

Jim

title: PATCH
body:
So, with this new understanding I am going to try some different questions
about PATCH.

1.  Is there a good reason to support the addition of new resources in two
different methods?  Addition of new resources can already be done through
the POST method, needing to recognize that the documents to be patched are
different is a potential error waiting to happen if this is not well
described in document.

2.  For the delete case, the patch string of {"href":null}  is more in line
with how I understand a JSON patch document to be designed.  The string of
{} would say that nothing is to be changed by default unless it is special
cased.  Setting the value of the href to absent or null would be easily
understood as saying remove the element.

3.  The text on patch needs to be clear on how to treat a patch document
where multiple occurrences of an attribute to modify occur in the patch
document.  It should also be clearer on the correct way to deal with
updating multiple occurrences of the attribute in the link document.  My
reading of the current text could end up with "</foo>;alpha=beta;alpha=beta"
as the output if the input was "</foo>;alpha=gamma;alpha=delta" and the
patch was {alpha:"beta"}.   I am not sure that is what you want to be
saying.

4.  This paragraph is missing some text I believe:

If the PATCH payload results in the modification of link target,
   context, or relation values, that is "href", "rel", or "anchor", the
   request SHOULD be rejected with a "Conflict" result code.

Why is this a SHOULD and not a MUST.  If you keep it as a MUST some guidance
on which rejections SHOULD occur and when they are acceptable would be
highly desirable.  Making it a MUST means that a Conflict response would not
be able to occur if I have my logic correct for anything other than an
addition request.

title: GET all registrations of /rd
body:
Hi Peter,

Sounds like we are basically on the same page.

In RFC6690 links, "href" always points to the target of the link, and "rel" describes the relationship between the parent resource that holds the link and the target resource. The other items are all attributes of the target resource.

So "con" refers to the registration resource, and reflects the "con" parameter that was supplied during registration.

Likewise, "ct" refers to the ct of the registration resource, that is the format that the registered links are returmed in. Anything that returns a payload has a ct.

Does it all make sense?

Best regards,

Michael


On Sep 8, 2017, at 2:46 AM, peter van der Stok <stokcons@xs4all.nl> wrote:

HI Michael,

For me it looks OK. A few reflections:
It must be clear in accompanying text, that "href" refers to the registration and "con" to the links of the registration. And core-rd.endpoint needs to be explained in text, and registered in core registry. Further, "ct" is an attribute of the links in all RD examples and not of the registration.

Cheerio,
Peter

Michael Koster schreef op 2017-09-08 10:08:
Hi Peter,
In your example, "loc" I presume is "location" which is how this is
returned in the response header when the registration resource is
created.
In my example, I propose a hyperlink to a resource, so "href" is the
usual key for this in a link JSON.
I also propose to include all of the link attributes including rt and
ct, so the client knows what it is without needing to infer anything.
So your example would look like this:
[
 {
   "href" : "/rd/541",
   "con": "coap://[fdfd::12]:17072",
   "ep": "example-endpoint-name",
   "et": "ocf-device",
   "rt": "core.rd-endpoint",
   "ct": 40,
   "lt": 600,
   "d": "floor-3"
 }
]
On Sep 8, 2017, at 12:25 AM, peter van der Stok <stokcons@xs4all.nl>
wrote:
Hi Michael,
I would have expected:
[
{
"con": "coap://[fdfd::12]:17072",
"loc" : "/rd/541",
"ep": "example-endpoint-name",
"et": "ocf-device",
"lt": 600,
"d": "floor-3"

With this information the rest of the link information can be
inferred.

Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-08-31 03:59:
I am wondering if there should be a GET action defined against the
resource directory object.  Currently, if an entity does a
registration for an endpoint it gets back a location for that
registration.  If a second entity modifies the endpoint and wants to
update the registration, it currently has no method to get the
location associated with the endpoint and cannot make a second new
registration since the <domain, endpoint> pair is required to be
unique.
Thus
Interaction: EP -> RD
Method: GET
URI Template: {+rd}{?ep,d}
Content-Format: application/link-format (or variants)
<rd/0099>;ep=endpoint1,<rd/0098>;ep=endpoint1;domain=beta, ...
Jim

title: multiple authorities per ep
body:
Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-09-06 00:14:
One of the issues that I just come up with, and might be part of an I
don't care space, is that if an endpoint has two different addresses
then the registration resource cannot have two different addresses
associated with it.  You cannot have two different registration
resources with the same endpoint name.  This means if I want to
register both IPv6 and IPv4 (or
other address types) with the same endpoint there is a problem.   I
also
just realized that same issue arises with schema.  These only apply if
you want to use the context parameter.  If you are going to supply
full URL addresses to resources then this is doable.  Given that the
context parameter is for space savings, I wonder if some method of
dealing with this should be considered.  Possibly defining some type
of context selector or something?

Jim

Indeed this is an issue that was also brought up by Dave Thaler, where he
referred to the multiple types of coap schemes that became possible.

For the moment, we made the model such that and extension to multiple
contexts is possible, but not yet supported by the RD, given that all
these
extensions are still under discussion,

Peter

One way that I have thought of dealing with this is to extend the check on
endpoint uniqueness from <domain, endpoint> to <domain, endpoint, context>.
The only downside that I can see is that it makes the query on the endpoint
resource slightly more complicated.

title: Clarify processing of lifetime with new registration of already registered device

labels.name: patch available
labels.description: There exists a pull request or other concrete text that offers to solve this issue

body:
According 

https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/blob/master/draft-ietf-core-resource-directory.md#registration-registration

> A new registration may be created at any time to supersede an existing registration, replacing the registration parameters and links.

and below

> lt := : Lifetime (optional). Lifetime of the registration in seconds. Range of 60-4294967295. If no lifetime is included in the initial registration, a default value of 86400 (24 hours) SHOULD be assumed. If the lt parameter is not included in a registration refresh or update operation, the most recently supplied value SHALL be re-used.

Therefore I'm not sure, if the explanation for the `lt` about the reuse of the most recently supplied value, just doesn't apply here (and may be moved to a more proper place), because this section is only about **new** or **replacing** registrations, or, if **refresh** or **update** registrations also apply to this section, somehow "extends" the behaviour of "replacing the registration parameters and links" (and may be therefore explicitly mentioned as exception in the "replacing the registration parameters and links, except the lifetime, where the below extra rule SHOULD be applied").

FMPOV, I don't see the use case, where a device sends a registration and the rd should use a previous lifetime without notice the device about that. The device would consider the default value, but, if the actual value would be smaller, the device will get unaware unregistered.

An example for "supersede" case would therefore be also a good idea, to clarify, what is intended.

title: Add a "Principles" section

title: Types of statements in the RD

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body: The lookup interfaces imply that there are four kinds of statements that can be queried from an RD: * res lookup `;ep=y;attr=z[;rel=a][;anchor=]`: There exists a resource /X relative to each address of endpoint y, which as attributes z. It is related to the endpoint or (if given) /B with a relationship a (defaulting to "hosts"). * ep lookup: There exists a host with some attributes (endpoint name, endpoint type) that is registered to the RD. It is a member of domains and groups as specified in arguments. * domain lookup: There exists a domain of a given name in the RD. * group lookup: There exists a group of a given name in the RD inside a particular domain. Are those the types of information obtainable from an RD? The text should be explicit about the semantics of what can be put in and learned from the RD, and not imply it by the way the lookup interfaces are described.

title: Principles

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body:
If we agree on some basic principles RD should follow, we can phrase them into a text that both guides other decisions in the RD design and can help implementers understand the basic ideas.

As I understand, those can be

* Statements obtained from the RD should stem from statements that can be found on the origin device (on .well-known/core or other ct=40 resources linked by it).

  As of -10, this is compatible but not enforced in resource links, and absent in statements about the whole device (where registration query parameters ep, et and d are exposed as resource attributes in the endpoint lookup)

  I'd treat commissioning tools that store information on behalf of the too-constrained origin node as an exception here. Another possible exception is the RD (or something interacting with it) making more statements true, eg. by registering the nodes's address in the DNS and thus making a resolvable (and possibly more stable) name available for use in con.

* An RD registration can only be updated using the registration resource (which typically only the origin device knows).

  If some entity (eg. a DNS-SD bridge) wants to update a resource's description (eg. change an instance name or rename an endpoint), they have to find (possibly through the RD) if and where the origin server allows such modification, and put the changes there.

Are those agreeable principles, and what else belongs in that category?

title: Domains as separate entities

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body:
(Summarizing a topic that came up in meetings and [on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/jFjEaM0PYK72dq-i1lOLwuc9To4))

Based on the notion of the domains managed in an RD being fully independent of each other "like ships that pass in the night", the idea has been brought up to do away with the domain functionality at all and have the domains exposed as different RDs by the server that would otherwise host a single RD.

Pro:

* This would align better with the general web design
* Issues with the domain lookup interface would go away (#21)
* This would be consistent with the use of RD by OCF and LWM2M, where the domains are used to separate 

Con:

* This enforces the independence of domains; setups where endpoints know their ep= but not their d= could not rely on the RD to assign them to a domain (the default domain for the given endpoint) any more.
* RD discovery would become more complicated (What would it look like at all?)
* Domains could not spring into existence any more by virtue of a device or CT registering at it
* Lookups could not span multiple domains any more

title: Semantics of the <>;x=... syntax in group and domain lookup
body:
RFC5988 (web linking) describes that a statement of `<B>;C=D` in the context of A means that "A has a hosted resource at B, which has the attribute C=D" (with the implied "hosts" relationship from RFC6690).

The repeated entries of the pattern `<>;d="domain-name"` currently drafted for the domain lookup interface (and the analogous group lookups) are bear no such meaning, and all provide statements about the same resource.

In a way, they could be collapsed into `<>;d="domain1";d="domain2"` (or `d="domain1 domain2"`).

Given it then talks about the currently used resource-directory (that is `<>`), isn't that a more straightforward to express the desired information anyway?

title: Discovery through proxies
body:
Writing up #19, it occurred to me that short of static configuration, none of the discovery options are available to endpoints that are only connected through a forward proxy. (I'm currently thinking of endpoints running in browsers connected through coap+ws, or coap/ws, as I've recently taken to calling it).

Is there anything we can do to make the RD available to such clients? My first idea would be giving "the RD" an anycast name like draft-ietf-6tisch-minimal-security-02's `6tisch.arpa` hostname.

title: Discovery of the RD: Make sure we want all methods, and argue which should be used
body:
There are several ways specified for finding a host serving an RD:

* static (unicast or anycast, addresses or DNS? could contain full RD path (as in LWM2M)?)
* various neighbor discovery derived
  * RDAO
  * the border router (ABRO)
  * "other ND options that happen to point to servers (such as RDNSS)"
* might-be-defined DHCPv6 options
* multicast (all-coap-nodes + .well-known/core; serves the path by design)

There is an open issue to describe how this can be used with DNS-SD (#8), and it came up 2017-04-07 that discovery via mDNS by those mechanisms might be possible but is not advisable.

Can we give a set of discovery options that should be supported by all general-purpose clients and servers to avoid fragmentation where one vendor's clients expect an RDAO while the other vendor's server relies on clients doing a multicast?

Can we say anything about which options are recommended to use, and which are rather to be viewed as shortcuts in extremely constrained cases? Using RDNSS would be a candidate for such a statement. Maybe those cases are better described as "explicitly configured to use whichever RDNSS is announced", so this is something that's better than static configuration but still not to be expected from a generic client.

title: Uniqueness scope for `ins`
body:
Within which scope should the `ins` parameter be unique?

The -09 draft (and the restoration PR #11) demands that it SHOULD be unique across all resources with the same `rt` and `d`. That is hard for the individual device to support out of the box short of adding its serial number to everything, and (given it's not a MUST) still insufficient for an RD exporter (eg. to DNS-SD) to use.

In the last meeting, labels for distinguishing two instances in a combined devices came up (two fridge compartments, `ins="upper"` and `ins="lower"`), which would violate that constraint when two fridges are present in one domain.

I'd suggest to either relax the uniqueness requirements and have whoever exports this to DNS-SD deal with the resulting ambiguities[1], or make them strict enough for ins= conflicts to fail early (an absent ins= would be such a conflict too, or is that a free pass to construct an `ins` at will?), and suggest a different mechanism for "upper"/"lower" distinctions (title?).

[1]: For example, as is done in the Z-Wave-IP, see design specification 4.1.2.3: "If several End Point Name and End Point Location entries are identical, the Z/IP RD MUST auto-append unique data to each of the conflicting End Point Names"

title: Drop "base URI" references
body:
All URIs of RD APIs are discovered standalone, and no relative URI or path-appending is required any more. Therefore, the term "Base URIs" and the distinction between "rd-lookup-base" and "lookup-type" in the RD lookup API are obsolete.

This has already been [mentioned on the mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7zzSmZK6Od1Rw3vzpaenN4G6otw), and [acked by Peter](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/NCLNlY8N__TCf9UMEq5yF1WxSJs), if I understood his response correctly (which I'm unsure about, thus tagging this for review).

body:

There is some confusion between where arguments can be used, but the "what goes where" of the link-format attributes is a separate issue to be tackled.

title: Add "ins" and "exp" link attributes
body:
"ins" (instance ID) is used to differentiate between two links which are otherwise indistinguishable. It is a text value which should be restricted to a maximum 63 octets.

"exp"is an attribute which provides a hint that the link may be exported to other RDs or other discovery services like DNS-SD
